titleStmt.title: Variants of derived forms V and VI PFV sound verbs

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for derived form IX (add an example).

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This example is by a 71 year-old male speaker.
This example is by a 65 year-old male speaker.

cit.quote: he got/turned red, he gets/turns red
he got/turned yellow, he gets/turns yellow
he got/turned black, he gets/turns black

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Particularly productive for color associations
The periphrasis ṣār + adjective is prefered (Herin 2010:234)
The use of this form is very limited, the construction ṣār + verb is more used. (Torzullo, personal observation from fieldwork conducted in 2021 and 2022)
This form is rather rare, instead of (i)ḥmarr "to turn red", ṣār aḥmar is commonly used. (Palva 1989:235)
"It is not common in Az, and it is limited to verbs of colours and physical defects." (Shawarbah 2012: 245)
Behnstedt (1994:88) states that the IX stem was mostly replaced by form VII and II. Only the two verbs smaṛṛ - yismaṛṛ and xḏ̣ arr - yixḏ.arr are attested.
The author states that stem IX is not attested in his data. However, native speakers would understand forms of the IX stem that are attested in Azēx.
Löhr (1905:49) states that the IX is used, but more often it is replaced by the verb ṣār (to become)+adjective.
Seeger (1996:72) states that he himself never heard somebody using stem IX, but that one of his participants assured him that it is in use.

In Maltese grammar and Pereira (2010) for Tripoli Arabic, this form is classified as an IX form. The form fʕāl, which is also found in the dialect of the Jews in Tripoli and which Yoda (2005) classifies as an XI form, is however neither fully reflective of the IX form nor the XI form.

cit.quote: he/it became red (intransitive, inchoative) OR he coloured [something] red (transitive, causative)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Panetta (1943) makes no mention of the form IX
The usage of Form IX is restricted to poetry, especially in participal forms like miḥmarr "pink".
"CōCaC is the original dialect form for colour verbs and inchoative and stative verbs which express" physical characteristics (Holes 2016:177)
The usage of Form IX is restricted to poetry, especially in participal forms like miḥmarr "pink".
"CōCaC is the original dialect form for colour verbs and inchoative and stative verbs which express" physical characteristics (Holes 2016:177)
Pereira (2010) attests is only in three verbs, ṭwāl "he got tall", šyān "he became ugly" and ḍyāg "he/it has become narrow"
Pereira (2010) classifies this as a form IX
The same form is classified as an IX form in Pereira (2010).
The pattern is remarkable for the final -a which is absent from the forms in other varieties.
Deduced from example.

cit.quote: is-sene zayne b-il-maṭar w-uxḍarr id-dunya šwayy
This year has been good for rain and everything got a bit greener.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Rather rarely used
Only used in the third form singular.
